author: 1deafea3b1d457bea99d4381ab8530ff
content:
I ordered the digital deluxe of this game, meaning I had access to play this game 4 days before its actual release and I have to say, this game is 100% worth it.
I did not expect much from this game and after playing through Hyrule Warriors: Age of Calamity, I assumed that this game would be similar to that playstyle and gameplay, since this game was developed by Omega Force. But, I was ultimately wrong and this game is nearly identical to the original Persona 5 game. I really enjoyed the gameplay and I enjoy the story so far. Persona 5 Strikers really does feel like a Persona game and I highly recommend anyone to play this game. 
8.5/10

author: fb76535271bb5190bfbeacb65dd8db76
content:
[h1]Persona 5.2[/h1]

Persona 5 and P5 Royal are JRPGs while Persona 5 Strikers is mostly a hack n slash. 

You can carry on and play this game but it is a direct sequel to Persona 5. There will be a lot of references to the original that new comers will not pick up on, sort of like if you jumped into FFX-2 and then moved back to FFX. 

The majority of the social aspects has been stripped away along with the daily life stuff. It plays like a destiny warriors but the story and reference to source material are straight up Persona 5.

Consider this a Persona 5 lite with the focus more on the story and combat changed to action based.

author: c2897166027a52c4b023ba04d16a0470
content:
나에게는 인생 최고의 게임

전투 방식은 바뀌었지만 역시 페르소나는 페르소나였다.

기존 턴제 전투에서 무쌍형 전투로 바뀌어서 조금은 걱정이 들었지만 게임을 하면서 
드는 생각은 기존 페르소나5가 가지고 있던 지루해질수 있는 턴제 전투를 완벽하게 
보완했다고 생각한다. 
바뀐 그래픽도 전작보다 훨씬 발전했다. 기존의 자세히 보면 어색할 수있는 카툰 랜더링 그래픽을
한층 더 업그래이드 한 느낌이다. PC판이다 보니 기존 스위치나 ps4 대비 로딩도 많이 개선이 되었다.
스토리 부분에서는 아무래도 전작인 P5를 해보지 않으면 이번작의 스토리를 몰입하기는 힘들다.
Ps4를 가지고 있지 않으면 P5 애니메이션이라도 보고 이 작품을 플레이하면 더욱 스토리에 빠져들수 있을것이다.
전작에 비해 이번 작품은 여러 도시를 배경으로 하고 있어서 진짜 여행을 하는 느낌을 주고 스토리 부분에서도 기존 P5 보다 좋았다고 생각한다. 
기존 P5는 플레이타임이 약 80시간 정도 나왔는데 커뮤나 알바와 같은 노가다성 콘텐츠로 플레이타임이 뻥튀기 되는 경향이 있었는데, 이번 작품은 그런 신경써야될 콘텐츠가 거의 없어서 스토리에만 집중할 수 있다.  

다만... PC버전의 버그가 좀 있는지 중간중간 크래쉬가 일어나서 게임이 튕기는 현상이 간혹 발생한다. 이게 내 컴퓨터만 그런줄 알았는데 스팀 비추천 댓글의 거의 대부분이 이러한 현상때문에 화가난 글들이 많았다. 아마 곧 수정될거라고 생각하지만 게임을 플레이할때 세이브 포인트가 나오면 그떄그때 저장하는 것을 추천한다.

스토리 10/10
그래픽 9/10
시스템(튕김 ㅅㅂ) 5/10
연출 10/10

플레이타임(노말 기준) 약 25시간

author: e32c4fe04cb65973bbc179f33bf68bd5
content:
So I've seen a lot of great reviews, so this may just be a me issue but I need to mention it anyways because I love this game and want it to succeed as I have genuinely enjoyed it since fixing this issue on my own. 

The control-scheme was very non-intuitive for the way they had it set up for people using mouse & keyboard. It doesn't play very smooth at all and I spent a pretty significant amount of time in the key-bindings menu trying to get things squared away. The issue was that there are so many commands, but the keyboard & mouse setup is designed as if you're just playing with keyboard, so the same buttons used to for left and right mouse are in the immediate area of WASD. This would be fine, if it didn't "push" other important commands to further locations from my hand on the keyboard, causing me to have to adjust my hand placement on the keyboard pretty regularly during fights until I changed the settings.

This isn't something that makes me regret getting the game, and I absolutely LOVE it now that I've adjusted things. Super fun and entertaining successor to the original game. 

*Minor Spoiler*

Just wanted knew players to be aware of this concern I had because the beginning of the game is heavy on combat tutorials. So even though it was guiding me how to play, it doesn't change the ease by which you can actually play. This detracted from my ability to fully dive into the introductory plot. Something that I definitely think the company should attempt to update in the future or at least learn from for future games.

Persona 5-2, thought it was gonna be a Musou game, but instead got a great Action RPG with amazing combat and it is a direct sequel to P5. Everything about this game rocks, from the art design, the new music, the graphics, gameplay, etc.

author: 98e8e72c2dbe540fad4fbe53c7a5139a
content:
[h1]-Overall Opinion-[/h1]

This is genuine Persona DNA through and through, even though the combat system is different. If you go in with an open mind you'll be pleasantly surprised with what they've done here. While it won't have a great level of tactical depth as a turn based Persona game, stringing combos together, pausing the action for a moment to bring out your persona and use an ability, it's all very seamless and well done. I'm enjoying the game so far, it really is a bonafide Persona 5 sequel (not Persona 5 Royal sequel). 

[h1]-Story-[/h1]
I am 18 hours in so this is an initial impression. The premise here is fine, we are basically moving themes from corrupt adults doing whatever they want to fulfill their own selfish desire to social media being a bad influence on young adults and making them do awful things to get over their complex and escape the judgement of their peers. Perhaps at the end of this there will be an in-depth commentary on the effect of social media on our collective psyche. It is serviceable enough in retaining attention, however, without going into explicit spoilers, I do find the recycling of some of the motives that compel the phantom thieves to do what they do to be frustrating. 

[h1]-Graphics-[/h1]
[olist]
    [*]Very Stylized ✅
    [*]Supports up to 4K ✅
    [*]Borderless, full-screen, windowed options ✅
    [*]Some text does not scale well at high resolutions ❌
    [*]Limited graphical options (bloom, motion blur, AA, AO, textures, shadows) ❌
[/olist]

[h1]-Performance-[/h1]
[olist]
    [*]Runs smooth ✅
    [*]Potato friendly ✅
    [*]Coin toss on if you'll play 4 hours without a single crash or one hour and crash 2 times. Patch needed.❌
[/olist]

[h1]-Misc-[/h1]
[olist]
    [*]Can be played with Keyboard and Mouse ✅
    [*]Supports key rebinding for KBM ✅
    [*]Soundtrack is absolute 🔥🔥🔥
[/olist]

author: 928fe43c8eec56c58d68447e7de8835b
content:
After 36 hours in I can safely say that this is not the Persona 5 experience I was hoping to get. The best thing about Persona 5 was how it blended together two different genres in one - JRPG and school simulator. Here you only have one genre - hack and slash with a little bit of RPG thrown in. This means that most of the time you will be doing the same things and that is it. And if you are not into the story, you will be left burned out from the experience. 

On the plus side I was pleasantly surprised that the iconic style of Persona 5 has been implemented into the new gameplay and locations. Also, the story is captivating and imaginative like in the past instalments and I do love the road-trip-in-the-summer vibe. The characters stay true to themselves and there are plenty of funny and touching moments with them. Not surprisingly the music is a blast and I do like that through DLC you may get the remastered versions of the previous games' battle music to play during the combat. Finally, the addition of cooking was a nice touch as well. Yes, there is sort of a cooking mechanic in the original P5, but here you need to first unlock the meal through a recipe, which can be collected in various ways, and then you need to gather the needed materials to prepare the meal as well.  

Where Persona 5 Strikers disappoints is in the core gameplay, environments and playability. While interesting at first, the hack-and-slash quickly becomes boring and predictable, even if it uses the weakness and Persona systems from P5. I prefer the turn-based combat as there the gameplay did not feel the same even after 100 hours in. You got the negotiations, the all-out-attacks and ambushes were more meaningful, the single vs all spells were more distinctive from one another, which Persona you had with you was more crucial. Here the gameplay practically boils down to casting spells, to which the enemies are weak, until you get to all-out-attack. Everything else has been simplified way too much. You can heal and restore SP via items at any time without any repercussions. Futaba tells you the weakness of the enemy in the beginning of the fight - bosses as well. You do not need to take down every single enemy to trigger an all-out-attack. Also, there was something terrifying and at the same special when you had to face off several enemies at once in the original P5. Here, because there are literally hordes of enemies sometimes you won't even notice some of them and they will soon all blend in together. 

The jails, themselves, have kept the unique environments from Persona 5 and they are not simply hallways. However, the feeling is the same as the one in Persona 4 - you go to a jail, do the same thing and end up in the same spot over and over again. There are no intricate puzzles, no surprise roadblocks or challenges. The formula is so far the same and thus, the locations feel the same, even if they are unique in their environments. The locations are also not exempt from this - sure, you will see plenty of Japanese cities, but essentially what you are getting per city are two mini locations filled with the same convenience stores and vending machines. Also, you can not do any extra activities in the cities - it is all just roaming the same street several times, buying several items and then going back to the Jail. Sure, occasionally if you talk to a member of the Phantom Thieves they might give you a side quest, which involves more than simply going up and down the map. However, the quests, themselves, are nothing that special and the missed opportunity to have a different version of a mini-game in each city is surely missing. 

Finally, while I said that there are plenty of character moments you are not involved with the characters that much, apart from the main story. One of the strongest aspects of Persona 5 were the interactions you had with the Phantom Thieves and the confidants, which happened outside of the main narrative. In Persona 5 Strikers you only get some boring side quests (like I mentioned) and some lines regarding the city / the particular moment in the story. 

I feel like I would be in the minority of people, who expected more of the game and were left disappointed, but I had to write this review down for anybody like me, who felt in love in Persona 5 and were eagerly anticipating this game. And can you blame me - they made Persona 5 Strikers look like it is a sequel to Persona 5. Apart from the story, it is anything but a sequel.

author: 1906e8df1e285ac192e5b59011d42972
content:
First Impressions/Short Review

Imagine if Persona 5 was more action oriented and you could pull off all of the action moves you wished you could have done in 5.  That's what Strikers is summed up simply.  It's got all the Persona flavor you know and love and feels like it fits in line as a great sequel.  Confidants have been replaced by Bonds but due to the way this one plays it makes complete sense.  Everything is more streamlined as you can quick travel easily between areas and transitions between screens/zones/The Velvet Room are much faster than 5.

Overall: Still a great amazing game, maybe not as great as Persona 5 unless you prefer action RPG over JRPG in general. Also it's clearly made for those familiar with Persona 5 already.

author: 4d2d38b3f38f5ecd9ff59e702e12b279
content:
The game plays and feels really good. The charcters and music are as amazing as the original Persona 5. 
This game has one problem tho. It keeps crashing. In around 18 hours of gameplay it happened 3 times. I lost around 2-3 hours re-doing stuff I already did because my game crashed. It really disrupts the flow of an otherwise really cool story and gameplay. 
There is no autosave, which was understandable in the original game with its playstyle, but here (in a game where you can get in and out of the jails with no repercussions whatsoever on time management AND get refills for hp and sp for the entire party) is just dumb. 
The crashes are a big problem that needs to be solved, but it would have been a tad bit better with an autosave function. Again, the game is good, but this is a major problem that needs to be a priority for the development team in a future patch (that needs to come ASAP).

author: e3f1904cd6165583a94a136e11a94e39
content:
Rollin back in here, still not done but hot damn this game does not stop. Does it slow down when it needs to? Yes.That said, I keep waiting for this game to become formulaic like its predecessor and it seems to be made specifically to prevent the player from getting complacent. Sure, there's a degree of predictability, but for the most part, it's a fun and unpredictable ride. 

What I've played of this combined with my experience with Astral Chain leads me to believe that, if Omega Force let themselves out of their own cage more often, they would easily outpace Platinum at their own strengths. Each game of theirs I've played since Dynasty Warriors 8 has begun to diverge further and further from the formula they used to strictly employ and it is completely for the better. Hyrule Warriors: Calamity was pretty good, but...I don't know if Atlus really knew how to draw their potential out of them or if they just were encouraged to just let loose and go wild but holy crap the gameplay feels great.

Couple that with the soundtrack, which the mediocre tracks in this outpace some of the best tracks in the already stellar soundtrack Persona 5 had and you have a mixture for a game that frequently just hits the damn zenith for what an action game can make the player feel.

All that said, the game doesn't forget the series it's in. Many have said it's a love letter to fans of the series and it feels exactly like that. The plot builds on the characters they spent over 100 hours feeding us backstory and introducing to us, and Strikers serves to just show us how all of them have grown, both individually and as a group of friends who haven't seen each other for a year, but still kept in touch.

I could honestly go on longer but I think the point is made, and I'd rather not spoil anything.

author: 3919e5213f5e595da8f80580d2e4a8d1
content:
[i]Persona 5 Strikers setzt in den Sommerferien nach der Geschichte von Persona 5 an und ist damit im Grunde eine Fortsetzung von Persona 5. Während Persona 5 allerdings, wie die anderen Persona-Hauptteile, ein rundenbasiertes Rollenspiel mit Social-Elementen ist, ist P5S im Kern ein Action-Spiel. Das Kampfsystem und die Dungeon-Teile des Spiels laufen also ab wie in Teilen der "Warriors"-Serie mit hektischen Kämpfen gegen Massen von Gegnern.[/i]


[b]tl;dr: Wem Persona 5 gefallen hat, der sollte auch P5S auf jeden Fall eine Chance geben.[/b]


Ich bin kein Fan von Musou- bzw. den "Warriors"-Spielen. Einige habe ich versucht, nach dem man ein-zwei Mal in eine Gegnermenge geprügelt hat, wurde das ganze dann aber auch recht trocken. Das ist bei Persona 5 Strikers anders, vor allem, weil sich Strikers immer noch vorrangig nach Persona anfühlt. Zumindest in den ersten 15 Stunden, die ich jetzt hinter mir habe. Kommt man drüber hinweg, dass die Kämpfe jetzt deutlich hektischer ablaufen, die Infiltrationen sich zeitweise etwas gestreckt anfühlen und man sich dieses Mal keinen Waifu-Harem errichten kann, wird Persona 5 eigentlich in so ziemlich allem solide fortgesetzt. Das neue Setting ist cool, es gibt eine Menge alte und neue Orte zu entdecken, die Dialoge sind super und der Soundtrack ist der Hammer.


[b]Contra[/b]
[list]
[*]Man kann keine Freundschaften mehr aus- und aufbauen, wodurch Abwechselung verloren geht. Entweder man kämpft, man bereitet sich auf Kämpfe vor oder es geht in der Story weiter.
[*]Die Infiltrationen bauen oft auf Fetch-Quests (Sammle drei X, um dieses Tor zu öffnen!) auf, was das ganze ziemlich entschleunigt.
[*]Einige Abschnitte, wo man für X Minuten ein wehrloses Teammitglied vor Gegnerhorden beschützen muss. Gibt es irgendjemanden, der sowas gerne macht?
[*]Die Kämpfe ziemlich unübersichtlich. Das wird an meiner Abneigung gegen Musou liegen, aber das Geschehen im Blick zu behalten während man 150 Shadows in alle Richtungen drischt, ist eine Leistung für sich.
[/list]


[b]Pro[/b]
[list]
[*]Die Phantom Thieves sind wieder zusammen! Die Gruppendynamik hat kein Stück verloren. Es macht Spaß, mit den Teammitgliedern zu quatschen und ihnen zuzuhören.
[*]Die neue Story und das Setting sind klasse. Man kommt an eine Menge neuer Orte und das Geschehen knüpft gut an P5 an.
[*]Jeder der Phantom Thieves ist (in den Dungeons) spielbar und hat eigene Fähigkeiten. Wer nicht mit Joker rumrennen will, wechselt einfach zu jemand anderem.
[*]Man kann Makoto spielen
[*]Auch wenn die Kämpfe nicht meins sind, man hat so viel wie möglich von den Mechaniken aus Persona 5 darin untergebracht, was das Ganze deutlich erträglicher macht. Auch das Fusionieren und Einsetzen unterschiedlicher Personas wurde ziemlich gut untergebracht
[*]Der Soundtrack hat neue Songs sowie neue Versionen alter Songs und ist einfach gut.
[*]Grafisch sieht das Spiel genauso gut aus wie P5
[/list]

author: d46fb6bfb3715025aa82544e45e7d748
content:
TDLR; Very fun gameplay but has only a decent story that gets the job done, has tedious grinding, and some pc port issues. 


Before I start there're a few things I'd like to note. PLEASE for the love of god wait for a patch. Now that I've been playing for longer the more and more issues I've been having with the pc version. It crashes often, leading me to lose progress, I've lost around 4 hours of progress in total which has been extremely infuriating. [b][EDIT: This issue has been resolved in the latest beta hotfix][/b]Performance has had dips, while not constant they're noticeable. The settings that come with the game do almost nothing, so i had to go into Nvidia control panel to make AA myself. At this point I cannot progress through one of the last jails because of a loading screen that makes my game crash each time. I do recommend the actual game but don't buy right now, will edit if there is a fix. 

Here's the actual review:

Wow ok I am pleasantly surprised by this game. At first I was worried about it being another generic warriors game but I looked into the game more and it looked more like a Persona game than warriors which is the case. So if you're worried about that, don't be. I've also been surprised of how big the jails are, you can run around them freely for the most part except from a few linear sections and minor puzzles.

The combat is so fluid. It incorporates almost all elements of Persona 5 in one way or another. You can pause time and use specials to hit an enemies weakness and then all out attack is just as satisfying as it was in Persona 5, whilst not as flashy.  Baton passes, 1 mores, buffs/debuffs, futaba support all make their way into the game as well. Fusing personas and using them in battle is still in the game, but not as expanded, which is fine and I only noticed a few times after forgetting. You can blast through the game for a lot of it but with minimal effort except the boss fights, the difficulty scaling is a little whacky. 

The story is worse than Persona 5 but it does have its charm. The story feels like a copy and paste for the first 2 jails but kind of picks up around the fourth jail, which I'm glad it did. The layout of the first two jails also feel similar which i'm confused by since they are supposed to be different. For what the story is overall, it's decent enough to warrant another journey with the phantom thieves.

Some misc. gripes I have with the game is that you never have enough SP so SP items are essential though they're hard to get in large quantity, but you can leave and re enter the jail with no penalty. The grinding in this game is so unnecessarily shitty for late game personas, it requires much lower level personas to reach a threshold in level before you fuse them. How do you level them up? Persona Points which are given in low quantities and increase the amount needed to level up a persona each time, this made completing the registry worse than in vanilla Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal. Camera can also be whacky but isn't a huge deal.

If I had to rate the game I'd give it a 8/10.

author: 6fee4577c0595c9aa93ad2b2ac411f6f
content:
Persona 5 Strikers é incrível. Não deixa nada a desejar em questão de história nos padrões de jogos da ATLUS. É um ótimo reencontro com os personagens de Persona 5 em uma nova aventura percorrendo o metaverso da psicologia junguiana com um objetivo novo, de ir atrás de Desejos ao invés de Tesouros, percorrendo Prisões ao invés de Palácios.
Strikers se passa após o final do P5, por isso, recomendo jogar o Persona 5 antes de Persona 5 Strikers (ou assistir um playthrough, já que ainda não existe P5 pra pc), por causa de algumas referências que o jogo acaba não explicando e para você se familiarizar com os personagens. 
A gameplay de batalha é bem diferente do clássico J-RPG e um pouco difícil de pegar o jeito no começo. O combate é meio-Musou meio-Personalike: você batalha contra uma porrada de inimigos na tela em um combate em tempo real e realiza golpes por combos, mas além disso, você ainda tem a possibilidade de utilizar suas personas, escolhendo skills, vendo o ponto fraco dos inimigos, viajando por dungeons no metaverso, e realizando ações como all-out-attacks, showtimes e baton pass. Por conta disso, creio que fizeram um bom trabalho ao criar um jeito de colocar Persona dentro do gênero Musou mantendo toda a essência do estilo padrão do game.

Ah sim, antes que eu esqueça de mencionar, os personagens novos me agradaram demais:
Zenkichi é mais um personagem do tipo investigador, que é um elo entre os phantom thieves e a polícia. O pouco que ele apareceu até agora já demonstra ser um personagem bem carismático.
Sophie/Sophia é mais uma "personagem misteriosa que não sabe o que é", padrão de todos os jogos de persona... Além de ser uma personagem que me lembra bastante a personalidade da Aigis (P3), e além de tudo, é ótima waifu, obviamente.

author: 76ee00fb2ead5072a862800e5c08de92
content:
I AM GOING TO HAVE EXTREME BIAS, Just look at my display picture or my profile. I'm a huge Persona fan, and the only reason I bought a PS4 was to play Persona 5.

Even if this game was crap I would still buy it, but surprisingly it isn't.
Even as someone who doesn't like Musou games this game is still super fun. The gameplay is still standard Persona 5, sneaking around ambushing enemies and doing all out attacks, but this time hack and slash instead of turn-based battles.

This game can be seen as a direct sequel to Persona 5, not the Royal version, and several references from the previous game can be found and it makes me so happy seeing those, so if you haven't played Persona 5 before chances are some jokes, and sentences might go over your head.

Anyways buy this game, show Atlus how many people want Persona on PC, cuz' I don't have the money for a PS5 once Persona 6 eventually rolls out, and more people need to experience this game series.

author: ca603c67cb595188b90bf78a9c35f449
content:
Bringing this game to Steam was a good move, but players really NEED the original Persona 5 or Royal first. Atlus should port that next to be fair. With that said:

If you're a Persona fan considering skipping this game because:

1)It's not "real Persona/Megaten"
2)It's not turn-based
3)There is no Social Link/Dating mechanic
4)It's not The Royal (Although please do not play this before at least vanilla P5)


PLEASE reconsider. This is in every sense still a very Persona game.


To say this is not true Persona is the equivalent of saying Persona is not true SMT. They are in the same family and are loyal to the spirit of the series. P1 and P2 did not have social link too.


Trust me when I say Atlus has gone to great lengths to ensure this game FEELS like a sequel to Persona 5.


This game is missing some elements which might disappoint Persona fans:

-There is no social link/confidant
-Persona fusions are extremely streamlined
-The combat is (obviously) not turn-based
-The calendar system is fully controlled by plot, nothing actually passes time
-SP depletes SUPER fast in the early game, but after a couple dozen hours I've begun to appreciate spreading out skills cleverly with normal attacks and combos. Leaving the dungeon to regenerate has no time penalty but is a bit of a time waster, should just have an option to skip the animation entirely tbh


DESPITE THIS:

-There's an abundance of "social-like" events and cutscenes, they're just integrated into the plot
-Some are actually optional and are nice breathers very loyal to Persona fashion. Some of these are also in the form of requests/sidequests.
-There's also a Confidant-like system that applies only to the Phantom Thieves. It's mostly automatic but there are actions you can take to increase the rank further. Rather than 10 ranks with set bonuses, you gain points to invest in skills of your choosing
-The Palaces (or "Jails") are pretty well designed from what I have played of them and are much longer compared to P5 to compensate for the shorter calendar. They are HUGE. Plenty of verticality in some parts and nice platforming.
-Yes it's simplified, but fusions are still pretty fun and skill inheritance plays a role
-BUFFS, buffs are still important in this game. If you're skilled you can chip away at bosses with low level.
-The combat is very flexible to your playstyle. A well prepared player can just use Persona skills, which stop time, and continually spam skills as if they were just playing a regular Persona game. You can also just stick to realtime and continually chain combos.
-Being able to control all Phantom Thieves and swapping between them in combos feels great
-There are many more areas to explore since this game covers a road trip, incuding P5's Shibuya
-Early parts of each Jail kinda feel like Persona 4's Intel gathering segments, but here there's a percentage on screen so you know when there's actual progress (less guessing)

In the 4 days of early access (Pre-Order) I've had 2 crashes to desktop after a cutscene. It was very random and I barely had any other issue.

Tips (You can probably ignore this if you wanna go 100% blind but there's no story mentioned here):

-FPS has 2 settings, 30 and 60fps, I believe you cannot unlock this.
-If your computer can handle it, set the resolution scale to 2.0x or at least 1.5x. At 1.0 the game's antialiasing is nearly non-existant.
-Use the tutorials menu! It's the only place you'll learn combos and they're **CRUCIAL**
-Shops restock based on plot and battles too, not just the calendar! Always check when you return from the metaverse AND make sure you know what shops have what so you don't waste yen. (YES even the vending machine trash is VERY IMPORTANT in this game, mostly early tho)
-Just like items are important, don't ignore cooking. It's very good.
-Use BOND skillpoints wisely. Money and Shop Sale are very good, but all of them matter.
-Upgrading the shop sale BOND skill will restock the shop, use this very wisely!
-Revisiting Jails has value as the requests system makes a return

author: d8737ec12bc15fe8ad0fe079ca81096d
content:
Persona 5 Strikers
----------------------------------
"I'll reveal your true form!" 

Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic blend of musou like combat, Jrpg progression and the persona world.
Its extremely well crafted, it doesnt even feel like a musou title at all.
The combat is Omega Force/Koei Tecmo staple. And that a good thing. 
The combat is fun and is solid musou action.

the world feels like a blend between musou and persona, open maps with parts to jump on or a city to explore and investigate. You wont get bored of the character interactions and when you enter the jail you can go where you want. Sneak up to a enemy and start the combat in a closed up environment that fixes the open musou combat from other Koei titles. Its more like a Jrpg.

Graphics are great and the soundtrack is just phenominal. 
I have a lot of praise for this title and you should get it as fan of the series, Jrpgs or musou titles.
its a perfect blend.

Now sadly the game is not the best port. Long loading screens and sadly crashes.
plus people having issues with fps and you cant play in full screen atm. (windowed works perfect).

With that said, i know they will fix it over time. And i'm here to review the game itself.
Its a fantastic title.

Enjoy the game !!

author: 787db0b8095656d9999c2188a891ebad
content:
You know how that period in Persona 5 where you finished Egypt Palace, you got summer cutscene, funny interaction between the party, the Hawai school trip and everything's bright and nice ? That's Persona 5 Striker but Haru's here and you're off to a roadtrip.

Gameplaywise it's looks like a musou and standard attacks are musou like, however it plays more like an action RPG in the same vein as the FF7 remake, if not faster and more busy on screen.

Trash mob is trash so you can musou however you want, instead the big meat is on mini-boss and boss fight where your standard musou square-triangle combo will never work because you'll get hit before finishing it,

In those case you'll go back to the gameplay of a Megaten game, where you'll use buff and debuffs (r), hit weakness using persona and keep yourself healed, all of this to break shields and initiate an all out attacks.

However this time, unlike the turn base of a Megaten/Persona, you'll be actively dodging the boss attack in the arena while switching characters and using special moves granted by environmental objects.

Keep in mind that's it's a full sequel to P5 (it doesn't explicitly show everything about P5 plot/endgame but you are expected to know the characters, their background,personality etc, so yeah it's not a point of entry game) , loading are a bit long even on SSD, and there's some weird issues with anti aliasing that makes the text ugly (removing it fixes that but the characters models in the menu will have jagged edges, it's totally fine in gameplay tho)

author: 50a051a79bd854f6a42a1cb7a668c0ac
content:
I played persona 5 and I'm pretty much the main character but in real life, so I decided to try out things he did to make friends and get girlfriends. I started by making a social link chart (like in the game) and writing down my social links. I act dangerous and mysterious like the main character and started wearing a blazer around when I'm outside (I bought a shujin academy pin.) I'm pretty far in my social link with the girls in the apartment next door, probably 6 or 7 with both of them. I left a calling card too (like in the game) to let them know I was going to steal their hearts. (I know in the game if you date multiple people it's bad but I have until valentines day to figure that situation out). Discord servers are like mementos, where I can dive in and debate people until I improve the worldview of that server. That's like the public perception meter in the game and I keep track of that too. When I get 100% I think they'll give me Mod on the server.

Basically, does anyone else do this stuff? I used to struggle with making friends and only kissed a girl once (she did not like it). But after playing persona and seeing myself in the main character spot I definitely have become a lot cooler and more attractive.

author: 23fb37764e9455d1a664c96895a12888
content:
This game can be described as a literal sequel to Persona 5. And it keeps it's standards. New amazing music and remixes, industry leading style and the kind of character building everyone loves about the Persona series. If one likes the action based or the traditional turn based combat more is a matter of taste. 

The few critical points are the fact that the story arc of P5 Royal is ignored within the game and that nearly all confidants from the base game are missing. (For real, I was so hyped to see Iwai again)

So, should you play this game?
If you played Persona 5 and liked it at least a bit: YES
If you haven't played Persona 5: Go get P5 (or P5R) for 20 bucks, have 100 very entertaining hours of gameplay and then come back and play this game.

Thanks bye

author: d1477ba72ed95cca855b917fcd436d3b
content: Surprisingly incredible. It's very clear how much love was put in to making it still feel like a Persona game despite the radically different gameplay style. The main game of Persona 5 will need to be played to understand the world, but this is nothing but a benefit since the game doesn't need to waste any time exploring the old cast. The story is very fun, the new characters are very welcome additions, the gameplay is addictive, and the soundtrack of course is godly. I can't recommend this enough to anybody who even slightly enjoyed Persona 5.

author: 171bd752411552c7bade04d67a6a4564
content:
I'm enjoying it hands down playing on hard mode and can't wait to play on merciless difficulty, also if ya don't know its a direct sequel of persona 5 vanilla (not royal) so if you haven't played the first you won't understand some of the characters feelings behind how they feel or what they're talking about in some instances please keep that in mind as well as large spoilers in the game if you haven't played vanilla or royal.

The game play is different from the usual persona games its like Hyrule warriors or Age of calamity, or better yet Dynasty warriors but I say like because it plays like persona with it's exploit weaknesses mechanics and also worry about your own.
The Story as far as I've gotten so far is very good, I've heard that it takes around 35 - 45 hours it's way shorter than the main games, but that's not bad at all honestly.

The combat feels fast paced, and if you need a breather for a sec you can pause and try to heal or take out your persona for time to stop while you select a skill. I playing on Hard Difficulty and honestly when I fought the first boss it took me a few attempts probably due to my low level or maybe lack of right skill for personas but I got it done, I honestly can't wait to replay the game on Merciless, which I believe it would be rewarded once you beat the game.

Give it a shot and you'll definitely find it worth it or just not your cup of tea!

author: 2b02f2c3f0835f89904d3924d52a1d27
content:
The sequel to persona 5 (Royal), As a PC only player I never got to play royal but I have played Persona 3, 4 and 5. The games are a gift. They are spectacularly flashy, great characters and great turn-based combat. This one is different. It is a Warriors/Musou game. This entail huge battles and being overloaded by enemies. I love the combat and I strongly recommend this games to fans of the series or fans of action games.

A caveat to this is that, it's a sequel. The game is 100% enjoyable if its you're first persona game or you've only played persona 4 Golden. It does have major plot spoilers to Persona 5.

A problem that the game suffers from is it is locked at 60FPS. This game would benefit hugely from unlocked frames.

All in all its a stellar sequel to persona 5 and a great standalone action experience. If you've played persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal it is a must buy.

author: bc8a98bb61315567bd50d38e64f7f77a
content:
Sequels don't work, at least most of the time. Spin-offs are bad, at least as a general rule. And then, along came Persona 5 Strikers, which serves as much of a spin-off as a sequel. It is by no means a perfect game, no game is perfect, but this is goddam near it. Atlus could have re-skinned a warriors game whit Persona, and i would have bought it. Instead, what i got was a love letter to both, the Phantom Thieves and the Players. 

This carries over a great deal of Persona 5. While some elements are shaved due to mechanics, most of them evolved with the gameplay change. Confidants are replaced by a bond system, you generate bond points trough certain requests or by fighting along characters. As expected the buffs from bonds are geared towards action games, more damage, faster bond growth, etc. At the same time this serves as a much friendlier system to the player, while still advances the narrative and deepens the bond between characters with the random personal request.
All the over the top action and showtimes are still present, and i must say, they are one of my favorite animations from the game, Atlus really brought out the personality of each Phantom Thieve trough this silly little animations. The combat itself feels fluid and gratifying, if at times a bit repetitive killing random trash. But where the game really shines is trough their boss fights. This has one of my favorite Boss encounters of the saga, and i thought it was nearly impossible to beat Futaba's Palace Boss. It could still use a bit more information on screen, like the direction and the type of incoming attacks from outside the screen, but it is by no means a deal breaker.

The downside to this game is, if you have not played Persona 5 OG you will probably feel left out on most of the conversations. A lot of references and inside jokes are beautiful winks to veterans of the saga, but might flew over the head of those not familiar with the lore, and i must say, this might lower your enjoyment of the game.

Overall i will say, give this game a change if you are a fan of Persona 5, if you haven't played Persona 5 yet, i will still recommend buying this one, as it is a very good warriors like game, and despite the random reference you might miss, the game does a very good job at exploring the characters and the narrative is A+ as i have come to expect from Atlus.

Pros

++Combat is fluid and rewarding
++Graphics are BEAUTIFUL
++4k 60fps
++Controls are very good and have a variety of schemes
++More P5 and Phantom Thieves
++Story Rich as any other Persona/Shin Megami

Cons

--Heavy loaded with references and inside jokes (not necessary to enjoy the game, but you do miss some of the enjoyment)
--No TIa Takemi ( SRSLY NGGS where is ma TIA)
--Somewhat short (about 40-50ish hours depending on how fast you rush it)
--No costumes DLC (yes for this game, that is a Con, trust me on this one)

All in all, if you are a P5 fan this is a 9/10, if you are not, this is easy an 8/10. Buy it now!!

author: 9655f781613451c0bfd13e65e2657129
content:
Danke das Ihr Euch die Zeit nehmt mein Review zu lesen. Wenn Du Dich fragst ob dieses Spiel was für Dich ist möchte ich vorweg nehmen das die Antwort in jedem Fall Ja lautet.
Ok differenzieren wir etwas. Wenn Du, wie ich Fan der Persona Reihe bist und auch Persona 5 schon gespielt hast, wirst Du Strikers zumindest mögen. Das Kampfsystem ist leider anders 
als man es bei P5 gewohnt ist. Was mich angeht ist Persona 5 Royal auf jedenfall eines der besten Spiele aller Zeiten. Kampfsystem, Story, alles passt peferkt. Die Story bei Strikers
machte mir auch wirklich viel Spass, das Kampfsystem ist zumindest ok und für Menschen wie mich lässt sich das Spiel auf Einfach stellen was die Kämpfe weiter in den Hintergrund rücken lässt. 
Für mich als totaler Persona Fanboy (ist man mit fast 50 noch als Boy zu bezeichnen?^^) war 
es gar keine Frage ob ich Strikers spielen möchte (danke an dieser Stelle nochmal an Micha, der mir das Spiel zu Weihnachten schon geschenkt hat ;3) Ich hab in P5 und Royal zusammen gut 300 Stunden gesteckt und werde Royal noch sicher mindestens zweimal durchspielen. 
Hat Strikers das Potenzial auch ? Ich befürchte nicht, aber denoch ist Strikers ein sehr gutes 
Spiel das ich jedem Persona Fan ohne Bedenken ans Herz legen kann. 

Wie oft betitelt fühlt sich Strikers auch nicht wie ein Spin Off an sondern wie eine waschechte Fortsetzung und allein deswegen ist dies Spiel ein Pflichtprogramm für jeden Fan.

Und wenn Ich Persona noch gar nicht kenne ? Ja Strikers wirft Dich direkt ins Geschehen und geht davon aus das Du Persona 5 kennst. Ich würde zumindest empfehlen mir kurz einen Überblick über die Story verschaffen. Dies YT Video bietet in 3 Minuten einen gaaaanz groben Überblick 
(Der Youtube Link wird immer als schädlich angezeigt. Wenn Ihr die Zusammenfassung sehen möchtet such in YT nach: Persona 5 FULL GAME RECAP in 3 Minutes!) 

Aber trotzdem ist man nach einer kurzen Findungsphase im Spiel und wird klar kommen. 
Spass wird IMHO jeder an Strikers haben der diesem Genre nicht ganz abgeneigt sind. 

Also, wir sehen uns in Shibuja :-)

content:
考虑到这是一款价格堪比新作的高价移植作品，整体说不上满意。
1. 画面&帧数：4K下狗牙较PS4 Pro少了很多，但依旧能看到；虽然宣传说4K@60帧，但3090跑4K还是会感觉卡顿，甚至包括在店里；
2. 操作：支持键盘和手柄，似乎不支持鼠标；XBOX手柄默认B键确认、A键取消，游戏初始设置里可以对调，但里面的大多数场景还是反着的，导致对调后手柄键位很反人类；
3. 其他：尽管是移植的，但作为一款电脑游戏，中途不能调整特效、分辨率，甚至不能在菜单里选退出游戏这点还是挺尴尬的。
希望阿特拉斯和世嘉不要只想坑一波，毕竟一个发售了这么久还能用近乎新作价格买的都是真·粉丝。

author: d8f4b21a38c3506eb906d5d9c807b99c
content:
Well, time to give a review on the sequel to one of my favorite games of all time.

[b]SPOILER FREE[/b]

[b]Story[/b]

Persona 5 Striker’s story is probably the most disappointing part of the game. Keep in mind that I did not care for the og Persona 5’s story so I had some doubts about this story going in. I thought the story would be bad due to the same reasons I disliked P5’s story, but the things that irked me in this game are different than what irked me in P5. The story is clichéd up the wazoo. It does, however, plays with some ideas and themes that work very well. It has emotional moments that work well and the story sets out to do what it wants to do. That is be a summer road trip story around Japan with the Phantom Thieves facing a new threat. My problem is that the story plays it SUPER safe. [b]Spoiler:[/b] [spoiler]It’s almost a repeat of og P5’s story, which is a shame.[/spoiler] It’s also very predictable. If you think to yourself “this person(s) probably the bad guy,” you’re most likely right. It’s very easy to tell where the story is going. Again, it’s not bad. It just has so much missed potential that completely bums me out. 

Whatever the case, you NEED to play og P5 before this as the game 100% assumes you know that game through and through already. Hopefully, they release og P5 or P5R so pc players can play that before this.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

Now, THIS I can get behind. Like many, I had some fears going into this game as I felt this game would be yet another mindless Musou game where you spam attacks and win. And while spamming attacks can get you far pretty early on, it won’t carry you much farther. P5 was half a JRPG and half a social sim. This game is 100% an action RPG. Some will be disappointed by the lack of social sim stuff, but I think the non inclusion of it allows for better pacing in the gameplay, and including it wouldn’t make much sense for the type of story and gameplay Strikers is going for. The new BOND system is a simple yet effective alternative to it I believe. The fighting itself lends itself so well to the warriors’ style of combat. Persona elements like weaknesses, technicals, personas, etc mix so well with it. Each character is a joy to control and each one is just different from one other. Each one of them has their own gameplay purpose. The combat is engaging, and constantly asks you to stay on your toes and use the most of your arsenal since not doing so will result in you dying FAST. Try spamming the attack button on bosses or bigger enemies and see how fast you can die. Using weaknesses and technicals as well as knowing what combos to use is key in beating anything in this game.

The Jails (which are similar to palaces to P5) were all fun to explore and it was joy to see just how creative they could get. Seriously, most of them were fun going through, obtaining loot, doing requests (which are fun and rewarding except the ones where you have to go to an area without getting caught fuck those), and beating shadows was a blast. Some of the beginning Jails are a bit too close in structure for my liking, but the game quickly switches it up, so it’s not a big deal. I do, however, feel that the game got a bit too easy at the end due to just how overpowered spamming weakness and technicals can be at times for the smaller fry. I was playing on hard and while it was certainly ballbustingly hard early on due to SP drain, the game got a bit too easy at the end for my liking.  

Other complaints include the lack of gun upgrades. I get the omission of social sim stuff among some other things, but no gun upgrades or customization? Why? That makes no sense since I actually like using guns in this game. Such a weird omission. Furthermore, persona fusing is super basic for seemingly no reason. I don’t understand why they simplified Persona’s robust persona fusing to such a simple state. However, other than the complaints I mentioned, I found the combat overall to be exceptional and constantly engaging. 

[b]Characters[/b]

The writing in Strikers is incredible, yet so fucking bad. This game got many laughs out of me and made me feel a lot. Likewise, the writing for the more emotional moments can get a bit too on the nose for my liking, a common problem for Persona, unfortunately. The villain(s) were MOSTLY good in how they went about their way of doing things instead of the one-dimensional cartoonishly evil villains in P5. However, some backstory for some of the villain(s) gets thrown in your face like 20 seconds before fighting them which felt cheap. The main characters (Ryuji, Ann, Haru, Futaba, etc) all remain the great characters they are, but they see little growth in the main story. I mean it’s there, but not enough in my opinion.

Now to keep it as spoiler-free as possible, I love the inclusion of Zenkichi and Sophia. Sophia is an adorable muffin that sees an unbelievable amount of growth in the story. It’s to the point where I consider Sophia to be one of my favorites in all of the Persona series. Zenkichi was amazing as well with a lovable personality and real growth, although not to the extent of Sophia. But they both remain absolutely incredible inclusions to the series.

[b]Music[/b]

It’s Persona. What do you think? Of course, it’s incredible. The remixes of P5 music as well as the original music in Strikers are all fantastic. [i]Counter Strike[/i] and [i]Daredevil[/i] being personal favs.

However, the audio mixing could use some work. The characters become REALLY difficult to hear during boss fights especially with the music is blaring. This can be remedied by messing with the audio levels in the in-game settings, but I hate that this is even an issue.

[b]PC PORT[/b]

What a disappointment. Firstly, the positives. The game runs at a stable 60fps all the time. I only ever saw frame drops during cutscenes and the velvet room of all places. Other than that, the performance is solid.

Now for the negatives. This game LOVES to crash. It mainly ever crashed for me during fast travel or loading screens. During my 60 hour journey, I crashed a total of 7 times. [b]7!!![/b] Sometimes I would lose upwards of an hour of progress. Do you know how much it sucks to bust your balls on a difficult boss only for the game to crash afterward without saving? Next, the game options are poor. The game is capped at 60fps. I don’t know if this is an engine issue or if the devs were too lazy to uncap it or what. Furthermore, the game still looks poor. Not the style, mind you (P5 style is still present here in all its glory), but the game doesn’t look enhanced at all for PC. Textures can be muddy and the UI quality REAKS. WHY IS IT SO PIXILATED?! Overall, a pretty disappointing port. Also, RIP mods.

EDIT 03/17/2021: New update has been pushed today that [i]seems[/i] to have fixed or at least remedied the constant crashing. So that's cool.

[b]Closing thoughts[/b]

Overall, my expectations were blown away by this game, as I was expecting not much at all going in. I was expecting a mindless button masher that would give me some kicks based purely on seeing my favorite characters get back together. It is a lot more than that in some parts, and in others not. It’s got its issues. It’s not perfect and some things really drag the game down. However, it does a lot right at the same time. This is a great sequel to P5 and a great, albeit very flawed, game on its own right.

author: f0f70860659f5f8688818592e23ae54c
content:
I really enjoy the Persona series so when this game was first introduced, I was already intrigued by it.

The game's story revolves around the life AFTER the original Persona 5 game, so if you haven't played it and care about the story, I would not recommend you to play this game first.

Gameplay-wise, it's decent. It's a hack-and-slash after all and all you are doing is just hitting random buttons and kill every enemy that is in your line of sight. Some fights will require you to use skills more carefully, such as bosses and dire shadows, but those aren't really that difficult as well, even on Hard difficulty.

Story-wise, it's standard. It follows the same story/plot of Persona 5 so nothing has really changed much in this game.

I only have 5 hours in this game and only just completed story 1. Game is really enjoyable so far and I will be sure to complete the game!

author: 387a777a756858d5bf211330f85acddc
content:
[h1] 游戏是个还不错的游戏，但是PC版的移植还不够完美[/h1]
小号已入标准版的同时，加上之前泄露的无加密版游玩已经有二三十小时有余，来说一下游玩PC版时发现的移植的小问题：
1、游戏不支持简体中文，没有像部分3A游戏那样的汉语普通话配音，这不是什么问题。
然而正因为游戏不支持简体中文，同时会因为简体中文字库的缺失，玩家在输入进简体字的同时，无法识别简体中文出现乱码。
这也不算什么，[u]输入法候选字的缺失，会白白浪费想用汉字给主人公命名的玩家几分钟的时间，使完成命名的操作变得更加繁琐，整个游戏给主人公命名的体验极差。[/u]
[spoiler]宛如2000年前后的打字体验，一字一个词输完了在一堆乱码中按space键看看有没有打对字？PS4版输入角色名的时候还会弹输入法呢...有没有搞错？日本人你们行不行啊？[/spoiler]
2、在不提供无上限帧率选项的情况下，即使锁定60帧有可能因为关了垂直同步的情况下会随机性产生屏幕撕裂。而且PC版跟PS4版的画面给我感觉几乎没有差别。
草，不说什么了。你们开心就好吧。
[spoiler]3、使用手柄游玩游戏时，实现游戏部分功能的键位设定不太合理。（这个看看就好）
一个前提：因为微软开发的Windows占有PC操作系统市场相当大的份额，加上Xbox同样也是实现微软主机游戏业务发展的产品，所以Windows会默认自带XInput API来实现官方及第三方Xbox手柄的连接，以及调用此API进行游戏手柄操作的开发适配。
在Xbox手柄默认按下方的A键作为确定的情况下，游戏却默认用B键来进入某个地点场所、发生对话来推进场景。对于习惯使用Xbox手柄游玩的PC玩家，这么设定会出现一种“割裂”感，因为Xbox手柄上的”B键“的位置恰好就是Playstation手柄的”圆圈键“所在的位置。你对话中间选择对话选项还是按默认的“A"键进行确定...按“B"键是无法选择对话选项触发下一句对话的。
其实如果，将幻影移动跟其他同样按B键实现的功能分开设定的话可能会好一点。结果还是想当然的按照原样草草试用就开始适配。要我看个人认为应该可以分开两个键位进行设定的。就进入场所跟发生对话时候也是跟A键一样确认即可。[/spoiler]

author: 5d13a6de0ddf5bd7a69aee8db13ae1f0
content:
If you love Persona series but don't like Dynasty Warriors's combat system template. I am glad to say it's far more than that. Sure, there are still mindless waves of fodders for you to smash them away, but they also implement tactical RPG stuff really nicely. You will find yourself planning the fight surprisingly a lot more than that. Most systems from Persona series are coming back and fit in really nicely (Elemental weakness, One-more, All-out-attack, Showtime.) It feels not out of place and keep it very true to the lore of Persona 5 in every aspect from gameplay, design, theme, and world's logic.

One thing that can be see as a downside is P5S is the direct continuation of Persona 5 (with some references to P5R too.) And it's not a small side story but pretty much a full fledged saga. They do try to rush out some of quick recap in the first hour but people without experience of  Persona 5 can find this sudden insertion to technical stuff too absurd for them. Is it needed? Not really. But your reaction would be "Oh! I remember that! Nice!" every thirty seconds to "WTF just happened?" based on your exposure to Persona franchise. Still a great game, but ATLUS and SEGA should really considered boosting this game with the Persona 5 Royal release on PC.

author: b25eefbc665f5f869a4e9b2e876cef19
content:
Jogo é ótimo. Sequência muito boa pro Persona 5. Problema é que em 15h de jogo ja sofri com o game crashando umas 4x.... Sem falar que algumas funções de graficos nas opções literalmente não funcionam, e qualquer resolução abaixo de 1080p deixa o jogo horrendo.

Não vale 300 reais nem se o jogo nao tivesse esses problemas, mas tendo complica mesmo kkkkkk. Espera uma promoção e compra. E atlus pelamor de Deus lança o Royal pra PC.

Edit pos primeiro playthrough: O jogo é incrível, muito bom mesmo. No momento estou na minha segunda jogada na dificuldade Merciless e posso garantir que se você gosta de Persona ou games mussou você vai gostar. Ainda não acho que 300 reais seja justo, mas numa promoção acho que vale muito apena. Não entre no jogo esperando combos complexos a lá devil may cry, é um action-rpg mussou não um hack n slash. No late game do jogo você vai mais spammar skill e o mesmo combo que usa aquela skill de graça do que qualquer outra coisa kkkkkk. Quanto aos crashs, percebi que (pelo menos no meu caso) eles são isolados nas primeiras dungeons e vou explicar porque acho isso: quando estava no final do meu playthrough, eu joguei literalmente as ultimas 2 dungeons inteiras sem nenhum crash, e assim que comecei minha gameplay no merciless, meu jogo voltou a crashar em Shibuya, não sei porque e óbvio que isso precisa ser corrigido, mas só de saber que não é o game todo cagado ja me da um alivio. Enfim... depois de zerar posso dizer que me diverti muito com ele, que os personagens novos são uns fofos (zenkichi ja é meu personagem favorito da franquia) e que o game apesar dos problemas técnicos é sim divertido

author: 8a052b28488b5a0abf1d099c0194d17d
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel to the original Persona 5 (You kinda have to ignore the new additions of P5R, sorry Kasumi!)
Storywise the game is so good and actually surprised me since I didn't expect a good story at all! 
But I don't want to talk a single thing about the story even if they won't be considered as spoilers because it's the best if you enter the game blindly! But also the game needs the player to know one thing and another about the phantom thieves, some other characters, persona aspects, etc. It's not 100% necessary tho but trust me you can't understand/enjoy much of the story if it is your first ever persona game! 
Many people think that Persona 5 strikers is a Dynasty Warriors game with a persona theme but nope, it's much more like a real-time action Jrpg than that.
The combat system is not turn-based anymore,instead it features real-time combo based combat which is a new&cool experience IMO. For me the combat was starting to get boring and smash button like in the first jail of the game but then I changed the difficulty to hard and also the game introduced more challenging enemies, so if you don't want to feel the same play on high or at least medium difficulty and also don't ignore dire shadows.
The combat is pretty enjoyable and a nice addition to the old turn-based combat system.
Many main factors of P5 or persona series in general are removed or been cut down in Persona 5 strikers such as Velvet room, Social links, daily calender system, and many other stuff that are all simplified/removed. 
Overall, P5 strikers is a must play for P5 fans who couldn't wait to see phantom thieves again! but if you haven't played P5 yet or even any other persona games and also if you can't get along with the new simplified aspects of the game,then you should probably ignore the game/wait for sales.

Now please keep bringing persona games to steam Atlus ! 

P4 Spoiler P.S: [spoiler] Adachi is the best striker! Such a pity he was busy buying cabbage so he couldn't make it to this game [/spoiler]

author: b29c4f9dc10c5d77a1460ffa4b9b5ba7
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is probably the best "Warriors" game ever made.
---
You play as Joker, a person with the Wild Card ability, which is a pass for using multiple Personas in the franchise. You and Morgana returned to Tokyo for your summer vacation, after planning for a barbecue with your friends, you were suddenly thrown into the Metaverse once more...
---
[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat is a combination of both Warriors-series by Omega Force and Persona-series, although it's a lot more similar to "Devil Summoner 2: Raidou Kuzunoha vs. King Abaddon", with the fluidity and mobility of "Warriors" combat. You'll still primarily press a series of buttons to execute your attacks and strong attacks, however, you can also pause in-combat to use your Persona skills or recovery items.
Each character, Persona, and enemy have their own kit, strength, and weaknesses. The way abilities are used by enemies will vary for each type of enemy, for example, Mara's "One-Shot Kill" would send a barrage of bullets towards the enemy (and 'stains' you for some reason), while Seth's "One Shot Kill" would be an explosion. This variation makes for a unique encounter for each enemy. You can obtain Personas by defeating them in the battlefield, or by fusing two (or more) Personas in the Velvet Room.
The hack-and-slash gameplay is vastly different than in other Warriors games. Each enemy will also have a "Knockdown Gauge" which, if depleted, will knock them down and enables "1 More" move and/or "All-Out Attack" for the player. You can deplete the gauge by dealing critical hits or striking the enemies' weaknesses. If the enemy still has "Knockdown Gauge", they won't stagger at all by your normal attacks, which lets them to counter your attacks by using abilities.
You can play as one of four characters that you choose before delving into a dungeon. Each character is actually fun to play, and each of them has certain characteristics in their movesets which are unique to them, which makes for a fun, different playstyle for each character -- something that is missing from modern Warriors games.
-----
[h1]Story[/h1]
Ah, the story. Before the story starts, there was an phenomenon called the "Change of Hearts" epidemic in which some high-profile figures confessed to many scandals, the authorities ruled out the possibility that the Phantom Thieves are the perpetrator behind this phenomenon and started an investigation against them.
Back to Joker and friends. After planning for a barbecue, they downloaded an app called EMMA, an artificial intelligence guide, which also doubles as an SNS app in which users can become friends with each other by sharing their "keywords". Turns out, some keywords will send people's Shadows to Jails within the Metaverse. With the Metaverse's return, Joker and the Phantom Thieves set out to solve the mystery behind it. Along the way, they were informed by a member of the authorities that the same phenomenon is currently happening in Sapporo, and the said member also asked the assistance of the Phantom Thieves to solve the case.
The Phantom Thieves decided that they would spend their summer vacation solving the mystery of the Jails and the Metaverse, while also having a road trip across various cities in Japan.
---
The story is a generic slice-of-life anime story with a pinch of "Shin Megami Tensei", typical Persona games. The 3D cutscenes and incredible voice acting makes the story interesting enough for me, that I can endure a 40 minute-long series of cutscenes.
Bottom line, the story is pretty good, but the duration of the cutscenes are probably too long for some people.
-----
[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
If you played both Warriors and Persona games, then you'll want to cross Easy and Normal out of your choices. Hard difficulty offers a tough but fair combat, and you'll risk of actually losing the battle.
After you beat the game and beat the ultimate boss, you'll unlock a new difficulty for New Game+ called "Merciless". This difficulty will crank enemy status through the roof, even early Shadows like Pixies and Jack o' Lanterns will easily kill you. Hell, the tutorial Bicorn feels like Chaos-Lu Bu where you can be killed in two hits -- even if you're level 82 with high-tier Personas.
So yeah, go with Hard mode for the first playthrough, and choose Merciless for the second playthrough. At least you won't be too surprised by the difficulty jump in New Game+.
-----
[h1]Cons[/h1]
Crashes. I experienced more than 12 crashes in my first playthrough, it often happens after leaving the Velvet Room, whenever cutscene background changing drastically (for example, from inside LeBlanc to outside LeBlanc), and leaving dungeons. Some even happen in the middle of a series of cutscenes after a 10 minutes boss fight. I really hope that this doesn't happen to anyone else.
------
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I had fun playing this game, 54 hours of hack-and-slash-plus-JRPG fun accompanied by an interesting and entertaining story -- makes for a game I would easily recommend to anyone. I hope that I can see another Strikers game again from Atlus and Omega Force.
-----
That being said, please port Persona 5 Royal to PC, Atlus.

author: 6122f21a578a5c9c8983a7b9ebcee9de
content:
Ce jeu n'est pas un simple musou-like avec un skin de Persona 5, c'est un vrais action-RPG qui implémente des mécaniques de la série principale. On fusionne toujours des personae avec des forces/faiblesses et on essaie de les optimiser durant de longue minutes dans la velvet room.

Evidemment c'est un jeu d'action donc exit le tour par tour, cependant le jeu reste assez tactique en difficile ou il faudra bien choisir ses partenaires et ses Personae en fonction du boss adverse et de pas oublier les buffs/débuffs.

Agréablement surpris de voir que chaque membre de l'équipe se joue différemment ! Queen peut ajouter l'affinité nucléaire a ses poings et utiliser sa moto par exemple.

Il y a aussi un petit aspect plateforming et infiltration (comme dans l'original).

Pour une certaines personne qui se plains que les voix ne sont pas les mêmes, je rappel (au cas ou) qu'il y a une pandémie dans le monde et que ATLUS West a fais un live pour la sortie du jeu pour expliquer comment ils ont enregistrés les voix (qui sont presque à l'identique, évidemment ce sont les mêmes acteurs).

Au niveau de l'histoire, rien de transcendant mais elle reste sympathique, c'est du niveau des autres spin-off de Persona.

En bref, si vous êtes fan de Persona et que les jeux d'action ça vous plait, vous pouvez y aller. 
Attention cependant, à l'heure ou j'écris cette éval, le jeu souffre parfois de crash.

author: ecd67f7254e65fd887abc060182ea937
content:
The unexpected persona game to say the least but ATLUS did a very good job of keeping this game, well... still in the theme of Persona.

[h1] Combat Mechanics [/h1]
To be simple, Turn-based JRPG turn Real-Time.
A lot combat aspects are still there, surprisingly. Exploit weaknesses, All-Out-Attack, Baton Pass.[b] THEY ARE ALL STILL THERE! [/b] I'm surprise of how they are manage to do that and make it work flawlessly. And the most exciting of all, the Showtime is just gorgeous!

[h1] Everyday Mechanics [/h1]
Apart from the cut confidant, not a lot have change. You start by gather the information about the target  and then you go in the dungeon now call "The Jail" and then you go to a total nut job mode. Sometime do a request and spend time talking with teammates or inside the RV. Basically the game loop is that.
Bond system is the new one that they introduce in this game. Similar to Social Links/Confidant but instead of going to each teammates and get their abilities, you get points to upgrades which you will need them.

[h1] Story [/h1]
Since currently at the time of this review I have not finish the game yet and I know that no ones want a spoiler. So the only thing that I'm going to talking about is how they tell the story.
The story goes on like in the Persona 5, you notice that something is going on in Shibuya just when the Thieves are having a summer trip and later they know that the issue is going across the japan in various cities. The story has to deal with trauma of "the Monarch", the ruler of Jail, that works like a Palace [b]with a twist[/b].

[h1] Sound and Music [/h1]
Talk about Persona without the music is [b]WRONG[/b].
Although Shoji Meguro, ATLUS house composer, is not the composer in Persona 5 Striker, the music still an absolute banger! Sound effects overall is perfect.
Right now I really dig "Welcome To The Jail", "Counter Strike", "Axe To Grind", "You are Stronger" and a lot more!

To be honest, the things that ATLUS did. This would be a bottom at my list of what ATLUS would do the their games and I have doubt at first about this being the Beat'em Up kind of game because I don't like this kind of game. But they really take my breath away here, got to give it to them.

[h1]Some After Thought[/h1]
What I said above is all true, this game is still a fantastic game and I urge anyone who interested in this game to play. HOWEVER, this game-by all means-still is not a traditional Persona experience. I still recommend mainline Persona more than this game overall. And since this is a beat 'em up game and this is a linear-story game, the replay-ability is next to none apart from the completionist gamer. So for me, the flaws of this game is really "It's not normal Persona" which is dumb. ATLUS did a thing that throw us off, and they done a fantastic job. The bitter opening of this paragraph will not effect my verdict.

This. is. still. fantastic.

author: bbd1a4fcf19e517f9251ba04df0659c2
content:
Absolute brilliant game. If you have played and enjoyed Persona 5 you will want to play this. The story feels like a worthy Persona 5 sequel and the gameplay is the perfect mix of action and Persona gameplay. The combat does for Persona what FF7 Remake does for FF7.

The game is not without it's technical bugs which will hopefully be ironed out. I had multiple crashes and consistent freezes when zoning into one of the dungeons which needed to be waited out to continue. I was more than willing to overlook these issues and power through as the game is just really good and hard to put down.

If you haven't played Persona 5 However I would recommend holding off on playing this until you have. (Hopefully Persona 5 sees a Steam release at some point. Please Sega) The story does very little to explain what happened in the previous game as it presumes you already know the events. Which is a good and bad things as this doesn't really spoil the story of the original too much if you were to play this first, but might leave Strikers only players confused about what/who is being referenced at times. 

This is a must play for Persona 5 players and for everyone else play both.

content:
정말 게임은 재밌긴 하다만, 구간구간 로딩이 긴 문제는 물론 아싸리 무한로딩에 걸려버려 게임을 완벽히 진행하지 못한다.
특히나 처음에는 아싸리 로딩 때문에 제대로 해볼 수도 없을 정도였다. 몇시간이나 박아 간당간당히 할 수 있었다만, 아무리 생각해도 로딩이 발목을 잡는다.
특히 무한로딩은 나만 겪는 것 같은 느낌이고 다른 데서 무한로딩을 겪었다는 글은 1도 못 찾아봤을 뿐더러 무한로딩을 해결하는 방법조차도 없다. (참고로 본인 컴은 게임에서 권장하는 사양 이상임.)
어디서 최적화가 잘 되어 있다는 말을 봤는데, 개뿔이. 최적화를 완전히 하려면 로딩 문제를 잡아놨어야지. 패치 전까지는 절대 완벽히 돌릴 수 없기 때문에 지금은 절대 추천을 줄 수가 없겠다.
당장 아틀러스는 로딩 면에서 최적화를 빨리 진행해햐 할 거다. P4G는 안 그랬음서...

author: 52d3f4c0153958fbbe3b46d43ff41738
content:
Imaginé que al ser desarrollado por Omega Forces sería un Dinasty Warriors con un reskin de Persona, pero me ha sorprendido para bien, combinando el concepto de estos de los combates con muchos enemigos en pantalla de manera simultánea con los elementos típicos de combate de la saga Persona adaptados a un combate en tiempo real.

Si tuviera que decir algo que echo de menos es la gestión de tiempo típica de la saga, aunque viendo cómo se desarrolla el juego es algo que entiendo, debido a que al contrario que en otros juegos de Persona es una historia que se desarrolla en mucho menos tiempo, aparte que no hay fechas límite como en otros juegos, así que perdería el sentido la gestión de dicho tiempo.

Respecto a los propios Persona, noto que hay menos que en un juego principal, pero no pocos. Comprensible, ya que aqui conseguir uno es tan simple como matarlo y tener suerte de que suelte la máscara, probabilidad que puedes aumentar con los puntos de relación que hay en el juego, no hay que negociar ni nada como en P5 o elegir una carta como en P4, y como no hay gestión del tiempo, con farmear en una zona puedes conseguir personas de sobra para fusionar o tener.

Yendo a la historia y personajes, la idea de las cárceles innova al dar algo similar a cómo funcionaban los palacios en el juego original pero adaptándolo a las nuevas mecánicas de este y dando una nueva vuelta de tuerca a las ideas del mundo cognitivo que se presentaban en el P5. Los personajes antiguos siguen siendo igual que buenos que en el P5, y los nuevos encajan perfectamente, tanto los nuevos integrantes del grupo como los monarcas de las cárceles y distintos personajes que van apareciendo.

La banda sonora es como siempre buenísima, y si compras la versión Deluxe como en mi caso, aunque es una tontería,  puedes jugar con las OST de batalla de los otros juegos de Persona, lo cual si te gustaron los juegos o su banda sonora, pues es un detalle extra que está bastante bien.

Como opinión final, aunque por el momento solo llevo 12 horas jugadas, me parece un buen juego, muy entretenido para los que hayan jugado al Persona 5, y para los que no también, aunque en ese caso te pierdes bastantes detalles del mismo al ser una secuela, ya que el juego da por hecho que jugaste al anterior y muchas conversaciones, dinámicas de personajes 
 y temas de la historia principal vienen del juego anterior.

author: 1d288d8364145a36b007a674401c54b5
content:
TLDR : A Refreshing take on the Persona franchise that actually works pretty well, with a few hiccups here and there. A solid game despite the lack of it's predecessor, P5 being on Steam (GIVE US P5R ON PC ATLUS / SEGA!) 

Full Review :

Persona 5 Strikers takes the traditional turn based combat gameplay of Persona and actually manages to make a pretty good hack'n'slash adaptation of it. Persona skills and all work well within a real-time environment, and you even have the ability to string them into combos for no SP cost too (SP is basically the "mana" of Persona, for the newcomers). 

The game does have one major flaw though in it's execution, the lack of the social aspect of Persona. In the mainline Modern Persona games (Persona 3 FES / P3 Portable / Persona 4 Golden (it's on Steam too go buy it) / Persona 5 / P5R) you have a big focus on the social side of gameplay, interacting with your companions, potential romance options, etc., which tie into the dungeon crawling aspect of them by strengthening companions you have strong bonds too. None of that is present in Strikers here, which is a shame. 

Strikers is also much more linear than the mainline games. That's not to say the mainline games I'm comparing it too had multiple endings or anything (P4 had like 7, P5R had 4 or so if I remember right), but they had a TON of stuff mixed into the social side, such as choosing whether to go out with friends (strengthen bonds) or do something to strengthen your own stats on a specific day. Speaking of days, in Strikers there isn't any time progression outside of story events, so unlike in the main games, there's nothing really pressuring you to pick and choose things, so you can basically just sit and grind if you want, which, admittedly works well for Strikers gameplay wise, but still worth noting the difference there. 

The game also lacks a lot of the Personas from 3-5 too, there's a lot, don't get me wrong, just MUCH more in the main games, though I'm not counting it as a negative thing, still plenty to choose from and you can easily use the Persona Points system (unique to Strikers, not in earlier games) and the accumulated power system to strengthen your favorite Personas. That plus the fusion system which is a Persona mainstay allow for you to easily take that level 5 weak Persona and turn him into a 99-Stat monster. 

The dungeons are also different here as well, they're much more open than the ones in Persona 3, 4 and 5, while keeping the similar style that dungeons in Persona 5 had. This is mostly due to the combat being you and the Phantom Thieves against a horde of shadows every time, but it works. 

Overall it's pretty great. If you haven't played Persona 5 Royal (or the base Persona 5) you may be somewhat lost with the terms and world of the game, but outside of the story of the Phantom Thieves and the Metaverse, you can still have a good time and know the basics. The story isn't as good as the mainline games either, likely due to it being shorter and more condensed (40 hours in Strikers vs. 100 hours in Persona 4 Golden or 150 in P5 Royal). 

Also, if you're wondering about the DLC under the game, ignore the All Out Attack Pack, but definitely go and buy the legacy BGM pack, as it includes battle themes from every mainline Persona games, even the old 1990s Persona 1 and 2 that nobody remembers. It also includes the very popular themes from P3, P3P, P4, and P4G, that is to say

- A Lone Prayer (Persona 1)
-Mass Destruction (Persona 3)
-Wiping All Out (Persona 3 Portable, from the Female Main Character's Route in that game)
- Reach out To the Truth (Persona 4)
- Time to Make History (Persona 4 Golden) 

You actually also get the themes from Persona 5  and Persona 5 Royal IN THE BASE GAME WITHOUT DLC, you just have to beat the main story and get a game cleared save file to get access to them, but the base game does come with a pretty awesome rock remix of Last Surprise (P5's theme) in the base game before then, it's pretty neat. 

I'd like to end this review by engaging in the time honored tradition of port-begging
*ahem*

PLEASE ATLUS / SEGA GIVE US PERSONA 3 FES and PERSONA 5 ROYAL!

Thank you for reading this review and I hope it helped.

author: 82ea18e36186520d93bd3bf643151fd9
content:
This isn't the first game collaborating with Omega Force to make a Musou/Dynasty Warriors spin-off from another IP, but it's probably the most unique. It makes you feel like playing a hack-and-slash warriors game with all the action RPG flare in it, but also a Persona/Shin Megami Tensei game with world map exploration and tactical battles. It's not a war game but an expanded take on Atlus' formula that feels the best of both worlds.

The story: Six months after the Phantom Thieves' greatest heist, the team gets back together for summer vacation. They get help to prepare from a super AI phone app known as EMMA, which supposedly can know all about user preferences and what you want/need to shop and where. But during a routine shopping trip and a run-in with an overly popular idol, Joker, Mona and Skull find themselves suddenly thrown into the Metaverse once more. As they escape, they discover an odd girl who introduces herself as Sophie, humanity's companion, who quickly lends their aid to the thieves. The team decides to cut vacation plans short as they get to the bottom of this situation, but things are worse than they appear. Inspector Zenkichi from Public Security warns the thieves that there are similar problems happening all over the country, and that Joker's the number one suspect of all the "changed hearts" happening. Not only must they clear their name, but prepare for another ominous calamity on the horizon.

Strikers is mostly for Persona 5 fans though as it'll jump in expecting you to mostly know what happened in the previous game (and that's vanilla form; no mention of "Kasumi" from Royale here). They do bring up references from the prequel whenever it feels necessary, whether it's to explain the new "Jails" work or bringing their newest member Sophie up to speed. There's even a clever interface where first registering EMMA you can put in the main protagonist (Joker)'s real name, as well as setting up other game options from voice overs to difficulty.

It definitely feels like a sequel and not that out of place from the previous entry. Unlike other Persona spin-offs that while having fun premises were very jarring and different from turn-based gameplay. A musou action RPG feels a more organic take-off than say, a 2-D fighter (Persona 4 Arena) or rhythm game (Dancing All Night, Dancing in Starlight, Dancing in Moonlight). It also feels more of a continuation to the story than fanservice for fanservices' sake, like with Arena or Q-Q2.

Back to gameplay, you have your options to attack with a melee weapon, shoot with a gun, or use a Persona spell for advantages. What's new is that you can also access a "special" command, which is kind of rudimentary in musou games like this. If the melee attack is your light attack, then the special is your heavy, and using any combination of these buttons can string combos for better results than just mashing attack over and over. In some cases, the combos allow you to use a Persona's elemental attack without using up SP and striking their weaknesses for extra damage. Every character plays different and feel more than just gated by their stats and elements. For example, Joker is nimble and balanced with his attacks flowing very quickly and his specials having the potential to change up based on what Persona he equips.

Joker is the only character who can collect and use different Personas that you face in the game as Shadows, which is benefited by entering the Velvet Room. Compared to examples in the original games, the Velvet Room feels more user friendly in that you don't have to worry about confidant links to power up through levels; you can power level them yourself and consistently as you collect Power Points from mask drops. You can even increase the level of your starter Persona, Arsene. Unlike most other Personas you collect, he gets new skills that scale up as he gets stronger. However, each level up costs significantly more points, and Persona level ups have fixed stats instead of 3 at random. Some increase all across the board (Strength, Endurance, Agility, Magic, Luck), some don't increase at all. Leveling Personas up makes transferring skills when you fuse feel easier, and instead of a complicated math program that determines what arcana/level between personas, they have predetermined fusions. On the plus side, when you resummon Personas to use, they stay the same and the cost doesn't scale up from their level, no matter how many times you register (save) their levels and spell list in the compendium. 

The game is very linear, and there's no rush to clear things in time unlike the prequel. You sadly won't see much of the supporting cast (Takemi and Iwai had their stores closed for the summer, for example, forcing you to rely on Sophie for shopping needs). But that means you won't suffer many time crunching consequences regardless of difficulty. You can buy all the items at vending machines/stores in the hub world, travel through a Jail for hours at end, grinding for money and treasure, then leave. The stores will restock to buy again, and the characters HP/SP will have restored to max reflecting their new earned levels. Time will move forward when you progress with the story, usually by accomplishing an intel task or fighting a checkpoint boss. You are free to take your time in the game, no worries. 

Sound is finicky at parts, as I swear I feel the mic for Ryuji/Skull's lines trail off as he mumbles his script. Music is mostly recycled from the previous game (or games if you got the digital bundle and get the option to change what battle music plays from across the Persona series). There seem to be only a few new songs, being Jail and overmap related. There are also remixes such as "Blooming Villain" that sound like a fitting theme for Lu Bu were he in this game. The character models look as great as they did in the prequel, and while there might be some off putting textures to some, I didn't notice a problem. Maybe it's because PC is running better than PS4 or Switch these days.

In the end, Persona 5 Strikers is a very solid game. If you like Musou Action RPGs with a limited but strong roaster of character to play through, this is one you should pick up. If you love Persona 5 and want to see more of the gang that steal hearts nationwide, then you should REALLY pick up this game.
